abstract.text: Declares a type that can parse an
value into an
value.

inlineContent.text: A parser attempts to parse a nebulous piece of data, represented by the
associated type,
into something more well-structured, represented by the
associated type. The parser
implements the
method, which is handed an
, and its job is to
turn this into an
if possible, or throw an error if it cannot.
The argument of the
function is
because a parser will usually
consume some of the input in order to produce an output. For example, we can use an
parser to extract an integer from the beginning of a substring and consume that
portion of the string:
Note that this parser works on
rather than
because substrings expose efficient ways
of removing characters from its beginning. Substrings are “views” into a string, specificed by start and
end indices. Operations like
and others can be implemented efficiently on
substrings because they simply move the start and end indices, whereas their implementation on strings
must make a copy of the string with the characters removed.
It is possible to seamlessly parse on different abstraction levels of strings. Working on high-level and
low-level
abstractions each have their pros and cons.
Parsing low-level abstractions, such as
or a collection of UTF-8 code units, has better
performance but at the cost of potentially losing correctness. The most canonical example of this is
trying to parse the character “é”, which can be represented in code units as
or
If you don’t remember to always parse both representations you may have a bug where you accidentally
fail your parser when it encounters a code unit sequence you don’t support.
On the other hand, parsing high-level inputs, such as
or
, can guarantee
correctness, but at the cost of performance. For example,
handles the complexities of extended
grapheme clusters and UTF-8 normalization for you, but traversing strings is slower since its elements
are variable width.
The library gives you the tools that allow you to choose which abstraction level you want to work on, as
well as the ability to fluidly move between abstraction levels where it makes sense.
For example, say we want to parse particular city names from the beginning of a string:
Because “San José” has an accented character, the safest way to parse it is to parse on the
abstraction level:
However, we are incurring the cost of parsing
for this entire parser, even though only the
“San José” case needs that power. We can refactor this parser so that “London” and “New York” are parsed
on the
level, since they consist of only ASCII characters, and then parse “San José” as
The
parser allows us to temporarily leave the world of parsing UTF-8 and instead work on
the higher level
abstraction, which takes care of normalization of the “é” character.
If we wanted to be
really
pedantic we could even parse “San Jos” as UTF-8 and then parse only the “é”
character as a substring:
This allows you to parse as much as possible on the more performant, low-level
, while still
allowing you to parse on the more correct, high-level
when necessary.
When a parser fails it throws an error containing information about what went wrong. The actual error
thrown by the parsers shipped with this library is internal, and so should be considered opaque. To get
a human-readable description of the error message you can stringify the error. For example, the following
parser fails to parse a string that would cause it to overflow:
Parsers may consume input even if they throw an error, and you should not depend on a parser
restoring the input to the original value when failing. The process of restoring the input to the
original value is known as “backtracking”. Backtracking can be handy when wanting to try many parsers
on the same input, and one usually does this by using the
parser, which automatically backtracks
when one of its parsers fails.
By not requiring backtracking of each individual parser we can greatly simply the logic of parsers and we
can coalesce all backtracking logic into just a single parser, the
parser. If you really need
backtracking capabilities then we recommend using the
parser to control backtracking.
If used naively, backtracking can lead to less performant parsing code. For example, if we wanted to
parse two integers from a string that were separated by either a dash “-” or slash “/”, then we could
write this as:
However, parsing slash-separated integers is not going to be performant because it will first run the
entire 1️⃣ parser until it fails, then backtrack to the beginning, and run the 2️⃣ parser. In particular,
the first integer will get parsed twice, unnecessarily repeating that work. On the other hand, we can
factor out the common work of the parser and localize the backtracking
work to make a much more
performant parser:

abstract.text: A parser that consumes a subsequence from the beginning of its input up to a given sequence of
elements.
Returns a parser that runs this parser, pipes its output into the given parser, and returns
the output of the given parser.
A parser that parses output from an optional parser.
A parser that consumes a UUID from the beginning of a collection of UTF8 code units.
A parser that attempts to run a number of parsers to accumulate their outputs.
A parser that consumes a subsequence from the beginning of its input.
A parser that runs the given parser and succeeds with
if it fails.
A parser that consumes all ASCII whitespace from the beginning of the input.
A parser that consumes a double from the beginning of a collection of UTF-8 code units.
A type-erased parser of
from
A parser that replaces its error with a provided output.
A parser that consumes a subsequence from the beginning of its input through a given sequence of
elements.
A parser that attempts to run another parser as many times as specified, accumulating the result
of the outputs.
Transforms the
of a parser.
A parser that transforms a parser on
into a parser on another view.
A parser that consumes a single newline from the beginning of the input.
Returns a parser that transforms the output of this parser into a new parser.
A parser that consumes an integer (with an optional leading
or
sign) from the
beginning of a collection of UTF8 code units.
Transforms the
of a downstream parser.
A parser that consumes a float from the beginning of a collection of UTF-8 code units.
A parser that attempts to run a number of parsers till one succeeds.
Returns a parser that transforms the output of this parser with a given closure.
A parser that runs this parser, pipes its output into the given parser, and returns the output
of the given parser.
A parser that transforms a parser on
into a parser on another
view.
Attempts to parse a nebulous piece of data into something more well-structured.
A parser that filters the output of an upstream parser when it does not satisfy a predicate.
The kind of values parsed by this parser.
Attempts to parse a nebulous piece of data into something more well-structured.
A parser that succeeds if the input is empty, and fails otherwise.
A parser that discards the output of another parser.
A parser that attempts to run a number of parsers till one succeeds.
A parser that can parse streams of input.
A parser that consumes a Boolean value from the beginning of a collection of UTF-8 code units.
A parser that consumes the first element from a collection.
The kind of values this parser receives.
Returns a parser that outputs the non-
result of calling the given closure with the
output of this parser.
A parser that succeeds if the given parser fails, and does not consume any input.
A parser that transforms the output of another parser into a new parser.
Returns a parser that filters output from this parser when its output does not satisfy the
given predicate.
A parser that replaces its error with a provided output.
A parser that runs the given parser, but does not consume any input.
A parser that always fails, no matter the input.
A parser that consumes everything to the end of the collection and returns this subsequence as
its output.
A parser that outputs the non-
result of calling the given transformation with the output
of its upstream parser.
A parser that attempts to run a given void parser, succeeding with void.
A parser that transforms the output of another parser with a given closure.
Wraps this parser with a type eraser.
Declares a type that can parse an
value into an
value.
A parser that consumes a float from the beginning of a collection of UTF-8 code units.
A parser that always succeeds with the given value, and does not consume any input.
A parser that parses a sequence of elements from its input.
A parser that can parse output from two types of parsers.
A parser that waits for a call to its
method before running the given closure to
create a parser for the given input.
